Three-an even greater obligation on our part to up-grade our standards of
presentation. Obviously, if the networks are going to start compet¬
ing with us on our own terms, we've got to be good.'
Four-just because we’re a booming, growing industry with an ever wider in¬
fluence on our collective community, let’s not be complacent. And
above all, let’s avoid that ’’Ivory Tower” attitude like the plague.
We must never forget our obligation to orient the listener, and show
him how the things we have to offer can be rewarding to him in terms
of his everyday life.
In short, we have a great future, ard an exciting future. But we can’t just coast
along on worthy objectives and lofty principles. We’ve got to keep working toward
constantly improving our end product.
As given at 1953 National Convention
Norman, Oklahoma
October 31, 1953
